HYPE Treasury Goes Public: Sonnet Shareholders Approve Nearly $1B Hyperliquid Merger  The digital asset treasury (DAT) sector just added another heavyweight. Sonnet BioTherapeutics shareholders have officially approved the long-delayed merger to form Hyperliquid Strategies, a Nasdaq-listed $HYPE   treasury expected to hold 12.6M HYPE tokens + $305M in cash - valuing the new entity near $900M.  Key points worth noting:  Hyperliquid Strategies has already filed to raise up to $1B through an SEC-reviewed public offering - potentially one of the largest DAT capital raises to date.  Hyperliquid, the underlying perpetual DEX, has processed over $1.5 trillion in trading volume since 2023, making $HYPE   one of the most active ecosystems among emerging altcoins.  Despite DAT valuations sliding during the recent market drawdown, the overwhelming shareholder approval shows that institutional appetite for structured on-chain treasuries is still strong.  With HYPE trading near $33 (down from $47 when the merger was announced), this move could reset liquidity, visibility, and institutional inflows for the entire DAT sector. #Altcoin Season#  #HyperLiquid  #HYPE

Arthur Hayes: Hyperliquid's success is hard to replicate, but the Perp DEX race remains undecided  

On November 3, in an interview on the Coin Bureau channel with host Guy, Arthur Hayes said that several up and coming Perp DEXs do have a chance to take market share from Hyperliquid, with success hinging on how well they execute market games such as token issuance and buybacks. He noted that Hyperliquid's rise from a few dollars to around $60 was a mini altseason in itself, yet no other project has replicated that success so far. Looking ahead 3â€“5 years, he expects Perp DEXs to siphon significant trading volume from CEXs. While he personally hopes Hyperliquid will be the ultimate winner, he added that it remains uncertain whether it can stay No. 1.

HYPE â€“ Structural Break, Liquidity Sweep and Target Continuation Setup


$HYPE is forming a clear bullish continuation structure after breaking intraday highs and shifting market direction upward.


The chart shows a decisive break of structure, followed by a controlled pullback into a refined demand zone, where price swept resting liquidity beneath the equal lows. That liquidity grab created the bullish catalyst for the next leg, confirming strong interest from buyers at the discount zone.


Price reacted with conviction, reclaiming structure and establishing a new higher-low sequence. With momentum now aligned and displacement favouring the upside, $HYPE is positioned for a continuation toward the marked target zone above.


As long as price maintains structure above the demand block near 33.0, pullbacks remain corrective rather than reversal patterns. The current behaviour reflects active accumulation and a sustained bullish narrative aiming for completion of the projected target.


#HYPE #Macro Insights# #Meme Alpha#

If it fails to maintain traction above this level, a potential short setup targeting the support at 32.59 could emerge, with deeper retracement risks towards 31.80 and 30.41. ğ—§ğ—¼ ğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğŸ’¥ğŸ¤” 

Taking @0xMertâ€™s advice, the team wrote a blog steelmanning every counter-argument against BAM. Refer to the link below.

Let's dive into it ğŸ§µ â¬‡ï¸ 
"ğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ—°ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—²ğ—± ğ˜€ğ—²ğ—¾ğ˜‚ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜„ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µ ğ—® ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—°ğ—¸-ğ—¯ğ˜‚ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—±ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ˜†."

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: This critique argues that BAM introduces a single sequencer that will do all transaction scheduling for Solana. Even if the infrastructure is distributed, the scheduling rules originate from one system, which is controlled by Jito. Stakeholders worry this undermines Solanaâ€™s natural diversity of schedulers into one that could behave like a centralized sequencer, becoming a single point of failure and concentrating too much influence in one scheduler and one party.

BAM is designed so no single entity can control transaction ordering.

The system will decentralize its operation and governance of scheduling logic through:
â€¢ ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—²ğ—» ğ—½ğ—®ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¶ğ—½ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»: any eligible operator can participate and run their own BAM Node.
â€¢ ğ—´ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—®ğ—¹ ğ—°ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—´ğ—²: BAM Nodes will be deployed across a geographically diverse network of operators.
â€¢ ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—²ğ—»-ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ—¿ğ—°ğ—², ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—³ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ˜€ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´: all BAM code will be open source and auditable via cryptographic attestations.

While it is true that BAM Nodes are currently solely run by Jito, starting in Q1 '26 the codebase will be open-sourced and independent operators will be onboarded.
â€œğ—”ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—±ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿, ğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—ºğ—² ğ˜‚ğ—½ ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¹ğ˜† ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—² ğ˜€ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—¿â€

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: This critique says that by opting into BAM, a validator effectively surrenders control over transaction ordering to a single scheduler. Instead of being able to run or adopt different schedulers, experiment with their own strategies, or switch between competing designs, they are bound to one system.

To enable Internet Capital Markets, Solana needs deterministic and transparent ordering rules. Fragmentation hurts users. BAM makes this possible with standardized, verifiable block building required by high-performance apps.

The facts are:
â€¢ BAM is strictly opt-in. 
â€¢ Validators can fall back to Agave, Jito-Solana, or Firedancer clients
â€¢ They can disconnect from BAM at any time

BAM Plugins offer a platform for optimization and developer innovation that benefits all of Solana.
"ğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğ—ºğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¼ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜‡ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—®ğ—»ğ—® ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—³ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜„."

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: Stakeholders argue that aggregating public transactions into a single pipeline creates a central chokepoint through which all orderflow passes and gives advantages to whoever controls it. Even if neutral initially, BAM controls order flow, which can reinforce its competitive position and prevent other solutions from gaining traction.

BAM collects transactions using the standard Solana TPU mechanism.

There is no distinction between "BAM transactions" and public ones. Validators receive the same public flow, just scheduled through a verifiable layer.

Validators can revert to their native TPU instantly with zero switching costs, keeping orderflow public rather than fragmented into private channels.
â€œğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğ—¶ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—²ğ˜…ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—® ğ—¹ğ—®ğ˜ğ—²ğ—»ğ—°ğ˜† ğ˜ƒğ˜€. ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—±ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿â€™ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—§ğ—£ğ—¨.â€

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: Stakeholders argue that one of Solanaâ€™s performance edge comes from transactions flowing directly to the leaderâ€™s TPU with minimal hops. Any intermediary routing layer, even a fast one, risks adding latency, jitter, and new points of failure under load, and could weaken IBRL mission compared to native TPU scheduling.

BAM ensures minimal latency via a global footprint of 100+ nodes and strategic co-location, keeping round-trip times under 5ms.

Our TEE stack is highly tuned using thread pinning and CPU isolation, achieving performance parity with Agave. With the upcoming migration to DoubleZero, we expect to surpass bare metal performance benchmarks.
â€œğ—•ğ—”ğ—  ğ—½ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—±ğ˜‚ğ—°ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜€ ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜„ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—±ğ˜€ ğ˜ƒğ˜€. ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ—¿ ğ—°ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ˜€â€

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: Validators have expressed concerns that BAMâ€™s scheduling logic might reduce tips and overall rewards vs other blockbuilder or scheduling opportunities. Additionally, Plugin fee markets are not yet live, making upside theoretical while downside appears immediate.

We prioritize long-term profit maximization. BAMâ€™s rewards are already comparable to Jito-Agave.

Past disparities were driven by temporary, extractive schedulers elsewhere that are being deprecated. Future yield will be driven by Plugins and ACE, unlocking sustainable fee streams from net-new economic activity rather than short-term games.
â€œğ—”ğ˜€ ğ—® ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—±ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¼ğ—¿, ğ—œ ğ—»ğ—²ğ—²ğ—± ğ˜ğ—¼ ğ—´ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² ğ—ºğ˜† ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—µğ—¶ğ—´ğ—µğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ˜†ğ—¶ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—±.â€

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: Stakers often choose validators based strictly on rewards. Even a small decrease in tips or variance in earnings across one epoch can cause delegated stake to flow elsewhere. Validators fear that adopting BAM early could put them at a competitive disadvantage if peers delay adoption.

We understand that validators must maximize yield for themselves and their stakers, but must also consider second order effects of their actions. Short-term yield hacking (sandwiching, slot-lagging) degrades overall execution quality and drives liquidity away.

The only sustainable path to higher yield is deeper onchain activity, which can only be enabled by better applications, deeper liquidity and tighter spreads.
"ğ—”ğ—½ğ—½ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—»-ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¹ğ—²ğ—± ğ—˜ğ˜…ğ—²ğ—°ğ˜‚ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» (ğ—”ğ—–ğ—˜) ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜."

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: Stakeholders argue that Solana applications already run well under Priority Fee and Tips inclusion mechanisms. Introducing ACE may increase complexity and create uneven execution guarantees between sophisticated apps and smaller developers. They worry that allowing applications to define ordering logic could lead to BAM privileging certain actors.

Sophisticated apps need guarantees like cancel-priority or liquidation-priority to function safely.

Hyperliquid does 10-15x the volume of Solana perps specifically because of its permissioned validator set that enforces strict ordering. Without ACE, these apps will migrate to custom L1s or L2s to get those guarantees.
â€œğ—™ğ—œğ—™ğ—¢ ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¶ğ˜€ ğ˜ğ—µğ—² ğ—³ğ—®ğ—¶ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ˜ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—®ğ—°ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—´ğ—¶ğ—°â€

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: Stakeholders argue that simple FIFO (first-in, first-out) ordering is the fairest and most neutral way to schedule transactions on Solana. It mirrors time-priority from traditional markets, is easy for users to understand (â€œif my tx arrives first, it executes firstâ€), and avoids the â€œpay-to-winâ€ dynamics of most blockchains.

While FIFO appears fairest by processing transactions in the order they are received, it encourages users to spam the network to secure a favorable position, leading to congestion and money-burning latency races. 

This breaks down when network demand is high, causing unpredictable delays for all users as queues lengthen. FIFO's one-size-fits-all approach fails to meet the needs of apps that require specific transaction ordering to function optimally.

ğ˜šğ˜µğ˜¦ğ˜¦ğ˜­ğ˜®ğ˜¢ğ˜¯: TEEs have a history of side-channel vulnerabilities, firmware bugs, and supply-chain risks. Stakeholders argue that relying on TEEs for block scheduling could introduce correlated failure modes: if a hardware exploit affects SEV-SNP, BAM as a network could be compromised. They also argue that TEEs shift trust onto hardware vendors and data center providers.

BAM runs on AMD SEV-SNP with cryptographic attestations in secure, compliant data centers (ISO 27001/SOC 2).

Even in a worst-case hardware compromise, validator keys remain secure and the chainâ€™s history cannot be rewritten, only the ordering privacy on that specific node is affected. Validators verify the "measured TCB" and can reject bad firmware via attestation.
